reviews.content: A taut film but Isha Talwar's intellectual egoism irritates.

WARNING POSSIBLE SPOILER


Article 15 is a 2019 pretty interesting Indian film.
It is in common use to define Bollywood movies as cringe and chaotic, however, driven by the desire to expand my culture I decided to watch it. (Of course in original language due to the lack of English and Italian, luckily there were English subs).
In the complex the direction is pretty good, I appreciated the idea of showing the huge fields of India and the lack of light during the dialogues to make them darker.
About the dialogues, they're well written but could be better.
I would have expected some scenes with traditional Indian dances, scenes that Bollywood has given us over the years without restraint.
The fact that this film has disappointed my expectation only makes me happier.

Conclusions:
the film is good and is a good way to pass the time, the story is fascinating, well shot scenes and fairly well written dialogues.
There aren't action scenes, the entire movie is built around the interactions between the characters. I suggest to pay attention to the dialogues, you could end up learning interesting things about Indian culture.
Honour mention to the soundtrack.

Article 15 refers to that part of the Indian constitution that outlaws discrimination on the basis of caste.  The title is sardonic since the movie shows the caste system to be alive and well.  I'm pretty ignorant of Indian society and politics so I found those aspects of the film a little hard to follow, and things get a little preachy at the end.
Movie which gives insight on the role of classes in India society.  Well acted, well paced, great script and story.  Based on true events.  Holds your interest throughout.
This movie shows what India is in reality. I've been there. And I saw exactly this kind of things. But the media pretends India is a democratic country. Unfortunately, it isn't.

Once a wise man said that the first step towards solving a problem is to first accept that it is out there. And works like "Article 15" points out the elephant in the room, simultaneously acknowledging the true power of motion pictures. Just like a high impact research paper, not only they can communicate with a vast audience, but also they can and will, make them think over and ask critical questions about what they often take for granted in the name of culture and tradition.
Deeply gritty story with a even deeper message. Wonderfully narrated story by Anubhav Sinha. Most main characters in the movies are realistic and believable. Cinematography is excellent.
A hard-hitting masterpiece.

A compelling and well acted movie that takes on a brutal set of crimes, a sharp look at a deeply imbedded caste system in India & the journey of its lead character to do the right thing in the face of everything against him. I really like this movie & the message it takes on.

Article 15 is a well crafted film. It allows the Indian viewers to see the reality of their society. The crime sequences are deeply captured out by the director. Every characters gave a tremendous work in the film. At last, the mystery is solved and they got the justice because of the careful investigation done by the star,Ayushmann khuranna!
A tough subject, but such a well-written, gripping film. Phenomenal performances by all. I thought about it for days afterwards.

A MUST WATCH.
Truly an amazing movie. I loved the fact that in spite of Anubhav Sinha being so focused on the main plot, he could integrate so many side plots that just felt as if they were happening in the same town, but the focus was not on them. Love the fact that the movie felt so real, it was as if you were literally transported to one of the same districts in U.P. or Bihar. The cinematography was truly amazing, the camera work just is so well done you actually feel you're in the movie. Last but not least, the point that the movie drives home is amazing, it's one of those movies where once you walk out of theatres, the principles, the values and the messages still remain in your mind to ponder on.

It's one of those films which had a strong premise alongside some social awareness messages but overly used Sub Plots and A confused route to the main Subject's conclusion made it less impactful.

Film starts on a great note, The asthetic beauty of the shots and a gripping background score catches our attention right away but as the film progresses That profound touch of greatness comes down on a lower note! Why? Cause of the too much inclusion of the other sub plots.

The main subject of the film was on the Castecism, Rape, The cruel reality of these Isolated places situated all over India but the makers somehow manages to bring up Political agendas, Rallies, Protests and all these Side issues unnecessarily into it.

In my humble opinion, the film itself had so much potential and strength into it's base story that nothing has ever needed to add into it. The makers should have focused more into the main story rather than investing their resources on other not so important parts of the film.

As for the Performances, All the actors have done tremendously well, Everyone gave their characters justice! The technical aspects of the film just like I said before were on another level. And the Screenplay & Plot despite the shortcomings successfully holds us until the end.

It's a pretty decent movie for the message and social awareness it produces but the unnecessary additions (Incl. The Main Lead's Fiancee Character) hampered the overall experience.

It could have handled the main concept much more maturely.

Article 15 is a gripping film with consistent writing. Anubhav Sinha, who already proved his mettle last year with the very intimate and deep film 'Mulk' which actually discussed Islamophobia, this time captures the horrors of caste system prevalent all over India. The structure of the characters is similar: there are interesting supporting characters playing the organs of governing system, and their is a wonderfully written duo of characters fighting the problem (Ayushmann Khurrana and Zeeshan Ayyub in 'Article 15', Taapsee Pannu and Rishi Kapoor in 'Mulk') but what makes this one a- somewhat- better ride is its thrills and performances. Ayushmann Khurrana is wonderful as Ayan Ranjan, the foreign return police officer posted in a punishment transfer to a town in Uttar Pradesh and the unsettling crime. With it's restrained depiction of the horrifying aspects of India's caste exploitation and a traumatizing observation of these mishaps and unfair practices, the film's dialogue is wonderful: it gets intimately close to the real world, and it deserves a thundering applause for even being a film made in India which defines the backward classes, not with respect, not with abuse: but as they are, in the most raw and poignant form.

Liked the plot and the activism. Didn't like the preachy parts, nor the over dramatized parts. Sound engineering needed work. The sepia or grey or blue tones and stylization of the images were quite unnecessary. These things made the movie seem more like a movie, less reality. This, to me, diluted the message.
the movie really great unlike other movies it show the reality that we often live in but we dont see it
Really good movie, directed well, gives a great message. There is a Big Need to emphasis this type of concepts.
You can't deny Ayushmann delivers a hard-hitting performance here. The film is gritty, raw and a slap to our conscience. It even shines brighter with the support cast acting out so brilliantly

A great man once said that the first step to solving a problem is first accepting its existence. Works like this remind us about the true purpose of the motion pictures. Not only they can communicate with a vast audience, but they can also and will, make the educated audience to think over and ask questions, what they often take for granted in the name of culture.

Inspiration 5/5 
Story plot characters 5/5
Usually such movies are made with crappy action. This movie will through the power of showing rather than telling and without beating bad guy up convince you morality.
The movie revolves around the caste differences in some parts of our country India. Overall the simplicity of the movie is mantained. And direction was great.

"Article 15" is a solid investigative thriller that's among the more serious efforts from Bollywood. The movie had my interest for the most part and had some strong social commentary. I felt at times the movie would build up a lot of momentum and then slow down for a while, which took away from the overall experience. This inconsistency in the pacing is my main gripe with the movie. Aside from that, I thought the performances were very good and the main story was very engaging. I think there are better crime thrillers out there, but this movie is still a good one that fans of the genre, such as myself, will like and should check out.
It's the kind of message that every Indian should try to convey to the mass . Totally worth watching it.

People Try to hide the truths of the society and that's what was shown in the movie + happened in India, People trashed movie theaters and force imposed BAN on this movie in some cities! 
Go And Watch!

It was one of the best movies the new-age Bollywood has produced hands-down. Although, I felt that Ayushman Khurana was constantly at unease while playing the part and was not able to soak himself within the character and felt new to the issues and genre, actresses and actors like Sayani Gupta, Mohammad Zeeshan Ayyub, Manoj Pahwa, Kumud Mishra took centre-stage with their emboldened performances and character arcs. The movie's power matrix and nexus is dynamic, there is no unsettling cheesy, mawkish glorification of anything of any kind and the movie keeps it grounded and real in its essence. The struggle to bring culprits to justice, the battle of getting victims exonerated and saved from the clutches of power-hungry, disruptive, manipulated law and order wins the audience. The climax shatters the superficial societal, legal roles and makes one think hard on the reality one faces just 100-200-300 kms far one's home. The swamp or the quagmire stands for a lot and the slippers of one of the abducted girls in that swamp becomes analogous to the situation of India grappling with its multifaceted problems in today's highly modernized yet helpless era.
Fantastic. Must watch.
This movie is very very nice movie..... This movie is good especially because of Ayushmann Khurana..... After watching this movie, this movie has become my favourite movie
Its an amazing movie
Uncomfortable and riveting. An excellent thriller that also shines a light on Indian society, revealing its unflattering horrors.
Awesome Movie. Not Like other Ones Never Feel Bored in Single Sec. No Songs

Ayushmann Khurrana has earned a reputation as a thinking actor whose movies are offbeat, original, well-written/directed/cast, with great performances from all the cast members.

Article 15 lives up to these high standards and my high expectations.

An exceptional movie.

The movie shows the bitter truth of of our society. Even after 70 years of getting independence from the Britishers, in many countryside areas, the upper castes are continuing their efforts to break the back bones of the lower caste people. They're more ferocious than the brutes. Even there are divisions between the Brahmins also!… Top brahmins, middle Brahmins, and so on. 😆
All these seems to be funny to me but when the question of the ARTICLE 15 of our CONSTITUTION comes, all the inequalities must be vanished.
Mind blowing acting of all the roles, not only of Ayushman, but of all the side characters also, makes the movie a splendid one.
Lastly I think the most important words of the movie are: "Why we need to form a King?"

Entertaining yet thought-provoking watch on the ground reality of the situation in the hinterland of India where religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth still play a major role in deciding ones place in life. The movie is inspired by multiple real-life incidents and is honest with its hard take social and political reality of the day. It does not try to be preachy, instead mirror the reality. The movie is supported with a strong cast of superb actors giving us compelling performances. The script is meaningful yet witty with some memorable one-liner humor.

Saw it 7.2.19 amc norwalk.  Terrific & real. Depicted caste system so evil.  Great acting.   Hindi (?) but english subtitles.  Indian rap music at end credits.  Best movie by far I've seen in a long time.  What do they call  that deep sonorous reverb music, like an eerie foghorn, that played almost throughout.  I've heard it in a lot of movies.  Very ominous, foreboding.  Scary.  It's gotta have a name.  But it's gotta be overdone soon.  Like, oh no, not that again.
It is not just a movie..... it's the truth of society....A Masterpiece 👍
